case_id: Rishi Anand & Anr. v. Government of N.C.T. of Delhi & Ors. (2002) 2 SCC 633
facts: Petitioners (Rishi Anand and Pranav Ansal) were Directors of M/s. Green Park Theatres Associated Pvt. Ltd., which owned and ran Uphaar Cinema in Green Park, New Delhi.
On 13th June 1997, during the 3:00 PM matinee show of the movie 'Border', a major fire broke out originating from a transformer in the ground floor parking area.
The fire and subsequent smoke resulted in the deaths of 59 patrons and injuries to over 100 others, primarily due to asphyxiation and stampede.
An FIR No. 432/97 was registered at Police Station Hauz Khas, New Delhi.
Investigation revealed alleged gross negligence and violations of safety norms, including installation of extra seats in the balcony which allegedly blocked one of the exit gangways.
The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) took over the investigation.
The Trial Court framed charges against the petitioners and other accused under Sections 304-A, 337, 338 read with Section 34 IPC, and Section 14 of the Cinematograph Act, 1952.

The specific allegation against the petitioners (Directors) was their role in the management and control of the cinema hall, implying knowledge and responsibility for the unsafe conditions, particularly the unauthorized extra seats blocking the exit.
The petitioners filed a petition before the High Court of Delhi under Section 482 CrPC seeking quashing of the charges, which was dismissed.
The petitioners then approached the Supreme Court via a Special Leave Petition challenging the High Court's refusal to quash the charges.
The Supreme Court heard the appeal against the order refusing to quash the charges framed by the Trial Court.
ipc_sections: Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention)
Section 337 (Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others)
Section 338 (Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others)
Section 304 Part II (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - Mentioned contextually but not charged by trial court against these petitioners at this stage)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Sufficient prima facie material exists on record to frame charges against the petitioners under Sections 304-A, 337, 338 read with Section 34 IPC, justifying the trial court's decision.
precedents: State of M.P. v. S.B. Johari (2000) 2 SCC 57 (Court cannot meticulously examine evidence at charge stage, only prima facie case needed).

State of Maharashtra v. Som Nath Thapa (1996) 4 SCC 659 (If evidence suggests strong suspicion which leads the court to think that there is ground for presuming the accused has committed an offence, charge can be framed).
Kanti Bhadra Shah v. State of West Bengal (2000) 1 SCC 722 (Detailed reasons not required for framing charge; prima facie satisfaction sufficient).
elements: (304-A): Death caused by a rash or negligent act; act not amounting to culpable homicide.
(337/338): Hurt/Grievous hurt caused by rash or negligent act endangering human life or safety.
(34): Common intention among accused (inferred from their positions and alleged collective failure to ensure safety, including knowledge of blocked exits).

counter_arguments.loophole: Establishing 'common intention' under Section 34 for negligence-based offences requires showing shared knowledge and intent regarding the specific negligent acts, which is difficult against directors without proof of direct involvement in day-to-day safety failures.
supporting_precedents: Mahbub Shah v. Emperor AIR 1945 PC 118 (Classic definition of common intention - pre-arranged plan).
Pandurang v. State of Hyderabad AIR 1955 SC 216 (Common intention requires prior meeting of minds).
Suresh v. State of U.P. (2001) 3 SCC 673 (Common intention can develop spotaneously but requires participation).

counter_arguments.loophole: Attributing *direct* criminal negligence (gross enough for 304-A) to Directors requires more than just their designation; specific evidence linking their decisions or culpable omissions to the fire's cause or the blocked exits is needed.
supporting_precedents: Maksud Saiyed v. State of Gujarat (2008) 5 SCC 668 (No automatic vicarious criminal liability for directors unless statute provides).
Sunil Bharti Mittal v. CBI (2015) 4 SCC 609 (Principle of alter ego needed to attribute mens rea to directors).
Jacob Mathew v. State of Punjab (2005) 6 SCC 1 (High degree of negligence required for criminal liability under 304-A).

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly applied the principles governing Section 482 CrPC by refusing to quash charges, as the power should be used sparingly and only when no prima facie case is disclosed or where there is abuse of process.
precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal 1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (Landmark case outlining categories where High Court can quash FIR/charges).
R. P. Kapur v. State of Punjab AIR 1960 SC 866 (Inherent power to be used to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice).
Didigam Bikshapathi v. State of A.P. (2008) 2 SCC 408 (High Court cannot act as an investigating or appellate authority at the charge stage).
elements: Jurisdictional limits of High Court under Section 482 CrPC.
Presence of prima facie case based on investigation material (challan, witness statements, reports on extra seats/blocked exit).

counter_arguments.loophole: If the allegations, even if taken at face value, do not constitute the ingredients of the charged offences specifically against the petitioners (due to lack of direct link/vicarious liability issues), quashing under S. 482 CrPC is justified as per Bhajan Lal guidelines.
supporting_precedents: Pepsi Foods Ltd. v. Special Judicial Magistrate (1998) 5 SCC 749 (Mechanical summoning of directors without specific allegations is abuse of process).
State of Karnataka v. L. Muniswamy (1977) 2 SCC 699 (If materials do not disclose offence, charge should be quashed).
S.K. Alagh v. State of U.P. (2008) 5 SCC 662 (Director not necessarily liable for company's offence).

defense_arguments.argument: The petitioners, as Directors, cannot be held vicariously liable for the alleged criminal negligence of the company or its employees in the absence of a specific statutory provision and lack of evidence of their direct involvement or mens rea.
edge_cases: Distinction between civil liability of directors and criminal liability.
Burden on prosecution to pierce the corporate veil, requiring proof beyond mere directorship.
precedents: Maksud Saiyed v. State of Gujarat (2008) 5 SCC 668 (No vicarious liability in criminal law unless statute explicitly provides).
Sunil Bharti Mittal v. CBI (2015) 4 SCC 609 (Director can be implicated only if there is sufficient evidence of active role coupled with criminal intent or if statute casts liability).
Sham Sunder v. State of Haryana (1989) 4 SCC 630 (Partner of a firm not automatically liable for firm's criminal acts).

defense_arguments.argument: The material on record does not establish a prima facie case of *gross* negligence or rashness attributable directly to the petitioners, which is a necessary ingredient for offences under Sections 304-A, 337, and 338 IPC.
edge_cases: Difference between simple negligence (civil liability) and gross negligence (criminal liability).
Need for the alleged negligence to be the proximate and efficient cause ('causa causans') of the deaths/injuries.
precedents: Jacob Mathew v. State of Punjab (2005) 6 SCC 1 (Criminal negligence must be 'gross' and involve disregard for life and safety of others).
Sushil Ansal v. State through CBI (2014) 6 SCC 173 (Later judgment in the same Uphaar matter, elaborated on negligence standards for directors/occupiers).
Mahadev Prasad Kaushik v. State of U.P. (2008) 14 SCC 479 (Act must be the direct result of rash/negligent act of accused).

defense_arguments.argument: Framing charges mechanically based on designation (Director) without specific allegations or evidence of individual culpability amounts to an abuse of the process of law, warranting interference under Section 482 CrPC.
edge_cases: Whether the investigation sufficiently differentiated roles of various directors/management personnel.
Application of Bhajan Lal guidelines regarding insufficiency of allegations.
precedents: Pepsi Foods Ltd. v. Special Judicial Magistrate (1998) 5 SCC 749 (Quashing justified if allegations are vague and don't specify director's role).
GHCL Employees Stock Option Trust v. India Infoline Ltd. (2013) 4 SCC 505 (Need for specific averments against accused director).
Thermax Ltd. v. K.M. Johny (2011) 13 SCC 412 (Vicarious liability cannot be imputed automatically to directors for company offences).

judgment.outcome: Petition Dismissed. The Supreme Court upheld the decision of the High Court and refused to quash the charges framed against Rishi Anand and Pranav Ansal.
reasoning: The Court reiterated the limited scope of interference under Section 482 CrPC at the stage of framing charges. The assessment should be based on whether a prima facie case exists based on the material collected during investigation.

The Court noted specific allegations regarding the unauthorized addition of seats in the balcony which blocked/restricted access to an exit gangway. This act, if proved, could constitute gross negligence.
The responsibility for ensuring compliance with safety norms and licensing conditions primarily rests with the occupier/owner/management of the cinema hall.

The Court found that the material on record (including investigation reports and witness statements regarding the extra seats and blocked exit) was sufficient to raise a 'grave suspicion' against the petitioners, warranting a trial.

The question of whether the negligence was 'gross' and whether the petitioners were directly responsible were matters of evidence to be adjudicated during the trial, not at the charge-framing/quashing stage.
The Court found no grounds to conclude that the framing of charges was an abuse of process or that the allegations did not disclose the ingredients of the offences alleged prima facie.
